Making single selections
Radio buttons are used when there is a list of two or more options that are mutually
exclusive and the user can only select one choice. Clicking a non-selected radio button
will deselect whatever other button was previously selected in the list.

Radio Buttons vs Choice
Radio Buttons and Choice component have similar functions, allowing a single selection
from many. Use radio buttons when only plain text is considered enough to
communicate the selection. Use Choice when selections can benefit from additional
information such as images, captions or values.

Radio Buttons vs Select dropdown
Radio Buttons and Select both present single choice selections. Choosing between
them should depend on the number of options available. For five or fewer options,
consider exposing the options as Radio Buttons as they are quicker to read and
understand.

Selection
By default, no pre-selection is made for the user, in order to ensure that the user makes
an active choice and does not submit information by accident. Users cannot go back to
not having any option selected. Where it is valid, an “I don't know” or “None of the
above” option should be included. If selection is mandatory in order to be able to
submit the form, and a user tries to submit it without having made a selection, an error
message is displayed.
Make an effort to only pre-select the recommended or most suitable and safe option for
the user, if the context and most common selection is known.

Radio Button layout
Radio Buttons displayed in a group should preferably be laid out in vertical lists to
increase readability. We recommend using no more than five radio buttons in a layout.
